hedline.hl1: You've Got Mail (cc: the Mario Brothers)

abstract.p: Interact Accessories offers cartridge for GameBoy that allows hand-held video game machine to send and get electronic mail; photo (S)

block.p: The problem with 10-year-olds is that they're disorganized, they're constantly late and they've always got their heads buried in some video game when they should be doing homework.
But thanks to a new cartridge for the GameBoy, they've run out of excuses for their poor behavior.

But thanks to a new cartridge for the GameBoy, they've run out of excuses for their poor behavior.
The Shark MX from Interact Accessories is an application that enables the GameBoy to send and receive electronic messages to and from any other e-mail account.
The Shark MX also comes with an address book, a calendar and a calculator so that owners can figure out just how much of their day is devoted to Donkey Kong.
Not much larger than a typical game cartridge, the Shark MX can connect to Interact's servers through any regular phone line.
After setting up an e-mail account at Gamesharker.com, players can use their well-muscled thumbs to compose e-mail messages on an onscreen keypad.

The device is $39.99 and comes with 30 free minutes of connection time. Each 60 minutes of additional time is $6, and the calls to Interact's servers are toll free -- cheaper than a BlackBerry pager or a Palm VII and a lot less likely to be lost.
